column1: Torrance is a coastal U.S. city in the South Bay (southwestern) region of Los Angeles County
column2: California
column3: in the Los Angeles metropolitan area. Torrance has 1.5 miles (2.4 km) of beaches on the Pacific Ocean. Torrance has a moderate year-round climate with warm temperatures
column4: daily sea breezes
column6: and an average rainfall of 12.55 inches per year. It is immediately bordered by Lomita to the east
column7: Gardena and Lawndale to the north
column8: Redondo Beach and the Pacific Ocean to the west
column9: and Rolling Hills and Palos Verdes Estates to the south.

column2: Torrance has grown to a population at the 2010 census of 145
column3: 438. This residential and light high-tech industries city has 90
column4: 000 street trees and 30 city parks. Known for its low crime rates
column5: the city consistently ranks among the safest cities in Los Angeles County. Torrance is the birthplace of the American Youth Soccer Organization (AYSO). In addition
column6: it has the second-highest percentage of residents of Japanese ancestry in California (8.9%) after Gardena.

column2: the area where Torrance is located was part of the Tongva Native American homeland.
the Spanish Crown deeded Rancho San Pedro (including today's Torrance)
column4: 000 acres (300 km2) in the Province of Las Californias of New Spain
column5: to soldier Juan José Domínguez. It was later divided in 1846
column6: with Governor Pío Pico granting Rancho de los Palos Verdes to José Loreto and Juan Capistrano Sepulveda in the Alta California territory of independent Mexico.In the early 1900s
column7: real estate developer Jared Sidney Torrance and other investors saw the value of creating a mixed industrial-residential community south of Los Angeles. They purchased part of an old Spanish land grant and hired landscape architect Frederick Law Olmsted Jr. to design a planned community. The resulting town was founded in October 1912 and named after Mr. Torrance. The city of Torrance was formally incorporated in May 1921
column8: the townsite initially being bounded by Western Avenue on the east
column9: Del Amo Boulevard on the north
column11: and on the south by Plaza Del Amo east of where it meets Carson Street
column12: and by Carson Street west of where it meets Plaza Del Amo. The first residential avenue created in Torrance was Gramercy and the second avenue was Andreo. Many of the houses on these avenues turned 100 years of age in 2012. Both avenues are located in the area referred to as Old Town Torrance. This section of Torrance is under review to be classified as a historical district. Some of the early civic and residential buildings were designed by the renowned and innovative Southern California architect Irving Gill
column13: in his distinctive combining of Mission Revival and early Modernist architecture.One of the nations largest shopping centers grew in Torrance - Del Amo Fashion Center
column14: and during the 1970s the Old Towne Mall combined themed amusement and nostalgia with shopping.

column1: Torrance is a coastal community in southwestern Los Angeles County sharing the climate and geographical features common to the Greater Los Angeles area. Its boundaries are: Redondo Beach Boulevard and the cities of Lawndale and Gardena to the north; Western Avenue and the Harbor Gateway neighborhood of Los Angeles to the east; the Palos Verdes Hills with the cities of Lomita
column2: Rolling Hills Estates and Palos Verdes Estates on the south; and the Pacific Ocean and city of Redondo Beach to the west.It is about 20 miles (32 km) southwest of Downtown Los Angeles.Torrance Beach lies between Redondo Beach and Malaga Cove on Santa Monica Bay. The southernmost stretch of Torrance Beach
column3: on a cove at the northern end of the Palos Verdes peninsula
column4: is known to locals as Rat Beach (Right After Torrance).

column6: and native plants. A Nature center provides activities

column1: Torrance has a Mediterranean climate (Köppen: Csb).
The rainy season is November through March
column2: as shown in the adjacent table.Summers tend to be warm and humid due to Torrance's proximity to the coast.The Los Angeles area is also subject to the phenomenon typical of a microclimate. As such
column3: the temperatures can vary as much as 18 °F (10 °C) between inland areas and the coast
column4: with a temperature gradient of over 1 °F per mile (0.3 °C/km) from the coast inland. California has also a weather phenomenon called "June Gloom or May Gray"
column5: which sometimes brings overcast or foggy skies in the morning on the coast
column6: followed by sunny skies by noon during late spring and early summer.

column1: As of 2014 the City of Torrance has the second largest concentration of ethnic Japanese people of any U.S. city
column2: after Honolulu. The city has headquarters of Japanese automakers and offices of other Japanese companies. Because of this many Japanese restaurants and other Japanese cultural offerings are in the city
column3: and Willy Blackmore of L.A. Weekly wrote that Torrance was "essentially Japan's 48th prefecture". A Mitsuwa supermarket
column4: Japanese schools
column5: and Japanese banks serve the community.In the pre-World War II period the South Bay region was one of the few areas that allowed non-U.S. citizens to acquire property
column6: so a Japanese presence came. According to John Kaji
column7: a Torrance resident quoted in Public Radio International who was the son of Toyota's first American-based accountant
column8: the Japanese corporate presence in Torrance
column10: attracted many ethnic Japanese. Toyota moved its operations to its Torrance campus in 1982 because of its proximity to the Port of Long Beach and Los Angeles International Airport
column11: and it was followed by many other Japanese companies. In 2014 Toyota announced it was moving its U.S. headquarters to Plano

column2: Torrance was once dotted with thousands of oil wells and oil derricks.  Though the oil wells are not as common as they once were
column3: the Torrance Refinery Oil refinery owned by PBF Energy in the north end of the city is responsible for much of Southern California's gasoline supply. Torrance was also an important hub and shop site of the Pacific Electric Railway.Torrance has a general aviation airport
column4: originally named simply "Torrance Airport" and since renamed Zamperini Field after local track star
column5: World War II hero and Torrance High graduate Louis Zamperini. The airport handles approximately 175
column6: 000 annual take-offs and landings (473 per day)
column7: down from the 1974 record of 428
column8: 000 operations. Airport noise abatement is a major local issue. In 2007 the Western Museum of Flight moved to Zamperini Field.Torrance is also home to the main bakery facility for King's Hawaiian
column9: the dominant brand of Hawaiian bread in North America. Younger Optics
column11: created the first seamless or "invisible" bifocal.The headquarters of Mitsuwa Marketplace and Nijiya Market are located in Torrance.

column7: near Dallas

column11: has the largest concentration of Japanese companies in the USA.

Wilson Park – the 44 acres (0.18 km2) park has picnic and sports facilities

column1: The Southern California Live Steamers Miniature Railroad is located at the Southeast corner of Charles H. Wilson Park. Free train rides on actual miniature live steam trains are given on the first Sunday and third Saturday of each month and the 4th of July. SCLS was one of the first live steam clubs in California started in 1946 with original members like Walt Disney
column2: Olie Johnston and Ward Kimball all of Disney fame. The club moved to Torrance in 1986 after leaving the Lomita Railway Museum property.

column1: The City of Torrance is a charter city.  The original city charter was voted on and ratified by the qualified electors at an election held August 20
column3: and filed with the Secretary of State January 7
column4: 1947.  The elective officers of the city are the mayor
column5: six members of the City Council
column6: five members of the Board of Education
column7: the City Clerk and the City Treasurer.Using the council-manager form of government
column8: the City Council
column13: and establishes the budget of the city.  The City Council appoints the City Manager and the City Attorney. The city has 13 appointed boards and commissions which advise the council on matters of concern to local residents
column17: and libraries.The municipality is supported by a general fund budget of about $160 million. According to the city's 2007–08 Comprehensive Annual Financial Report
column18: the city's various funds had $193 million in Revenues
column22: and $140 million in cash in investments.

column1: Torrance Police Department provides 24-hour law enforcement coverage to the city. The department is broken down into four major divisions
column2: each with its own subdivisions. The department has one main station located at the Civic Center near City Hall. It houses the administrative offices
column4: and the public safety dispatch center. The department works closely with other local law enforcement agencies for training and SWAT operations. The police chief is Eve R. Irvine.

column1: Torrance operates its own 911 dispatch center located at the police station
column2: and is responsible for all 911 calls originating in Torrance. The communications center answers emergency and non-emergency calls and requests for assistance in addition to dispatching for both the Fire and Police Departments.

As of February 1990 neighbors of the campus site were asking the City of Torrance to not modify the zoning of this property. The Lycee stated that the campus closed due to low enrollment.At one time
